abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Renewable Energy Market
            Transformation (REMT) Project for South Africa were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to global
            environment outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: well-targeted technical
            assistance (TA) activities, although time consuming, can
            support the enabling conditions for scale-up of RE markets.
            Well-designed pre-financing and financing mechanisms for RE
            projects are key elements of scale-up of RE investments.
            South Africa combined elements of both feed-in-tariffs and
            competitive tendering in the implementation of the Renewable
            Energy Independent Power Producer Procurement Program
            (REIPPPP), creating a replicable model of RE development for
            other countries. Flexible project design allows clients to
            move quickly to adjust to changing global market conditions.
            Effective project implementation seeks to harmonize with the
            country's broader and urgent goals. Creating dedicated
            in-house project management capacity by locating the
            implementation support unit (ISU) at the department of
            energy (DoE) can have been considered as an option.
            Attracting and retaining qualified personnel on the basis of
            fixed-term employment contracts can be a challenge for
            project implementation. The engaged and flexible approach
            demonstrated by the ISU, the DoE, and the World Bank during
            implementation was critical in maintaining the
            project's relevance during a period of considerable
            policy change. Reducing turnaround time for procurement of
            consultants will have helped the project become even more
            responsive in a fast-moving policy and regulatory
            environment. Engaging small RE enterprises to participate in
            the REMT matching grants (MG) program is a time-and
            resource-intensive activity and requires a significant level
            of ISU support. Successful projects require close oversight
            and engaged supervision with sufficient budgets.
